Award.AwardTitle: Determining Teachers baseline practice and alignment prior to a systemic curriculum change

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of this research is to document current teaching practices prior to the systemic integration of the Next Generation Science Standards (NGSS) in Baltimore City Public schools. In this study, UMBC will collaborate with Baltimore City Public Schools (City Schools) to collect and document teacher classroom practices prior to the implementation of an extended professional development model that targets pedagogical skills associated with the Next Generation Science Standards. The broad objective of the project is to characterize the benefits and limitations of utilizing controlled practice-teaching as a key component of teacher professional development for integrating NGSS aligned practices in middle school science classrooms. Success will be measured by changes in teacher attitudes, enhancement of teacher pedagogical skills and student learning gains. Sixty teachers, and over 4,500 students in Baltimore City will be directly impacted through the professional development and curriculum enactment efforts proposed. As a full partner in the project, the City Schools' leadership will also learn what works, for whom, and under what conditions in schools that are representative of their diverse district. Lessons learned have the potential to inform the implementation of other new reform initiatives within City Schools and beyond. Findings from the proposed research have the potential to advance our understanding of innovative professional development strategies and their impact on classroom practices and student learning.

This project focuses on a national need of models for high quality professional development that directly tie specific strategies to classroom-based instructional changes and student learning outcomes. One particular shift in classroom practice that is fundamental for the classroom implementation of NGSS is scientific discourse and argumentation. One particular strategy that has shown promise for supporting teachers' use of strategies supporting argumentation is the use of controlled practice teaching. The proposed study explicitly attempts to determine the impact of the controlled practice-teaching using a quasi-experimental design. The research plan involves middle science teachers being assigned to one of two experimental conditions (PD including or excluding a controlled practice-teaching component) and then to investigate potential differences among the two treatments and control conditions related to changes in attitudes toward NGSS, classroom practices and impact on student learning. The researcher hypothesizes that the inclusion of control-practice teaching that is imbedded in a sustained professional development program will promote the development of teacher pedagogical skills aligned with NGSS more effectively than sustained professional development that does not include a control-practice component.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The intellectual merit of this project focuses on a national need of models for high quality professional development (PD) that directly tie specific strategies to classroom-based instructional changes and student learning outcomes.  This issue is particularly relevant considering the significant changes in STEM education articulated in the Next Generation Science Standards (NGSS).  Current instructional changes in Baltimore City Public Schools in response to NGSS presented a strong model. 

 

The UMBC-Baltimore City Public Schools RAPID proposal was designed to capture and document current instructional practices and attitudes of middle school science teachers as they related to the newly adopted NGSS.   Middle school science teachers in Baltimore City Public Schools (City Schools) were currently embarking on a major curricular and pedagogical shift as a result of adopting NGSS. Funding of this RAPID proposal was supported by the rarity of the contextual events being studied (e.g. large urban district-wide adoption of new curricular standards and aligned materials) as well as by the importance of the data being collected for establishing baseline performance levels.   Establishing baseline data is vital in order to determine potential impact of future professional development interventions.    

Multiple events for recruiting teachers occurred in spring 2018, fall of 2018 and spring 2019.  Recruitment flyers were submitted through the City Schools internal electronic network, with follow-up in person events scheduled at system wide teacher in-service day (10/18/18) as well as multiple after school events (3/11/18 & 3/18/18).  In addition, a 2-day workshop was presented on June 19 & 20, 2018 as an additional effort to recruit teachers.  

The recruitment efforts did produce interest from a total of 69 teachers. The teacher workshop that was used as a recruitment incentive held on June 19 &20 (2018) had 30 middle school science teachers from Baltimore City in attendance.  Of the 69 teachers that expressed interest, 37 submitted completed applications for joining the study.  From the 37 completed applications, 21 lessons were scheduled and recorded for baseline scoring. 

 

Considering the foundational design of the NGSS aligned materials a new observational coding scheme was utilized.  The scheme was designed by Kate McNeil, Katsh-Singer, and Pam Pelletier, 2015) and was designed specifically for assessing the 8 science practices advocated in the Next Generation Science Standards. 

 

Collected classroom videos were scored by two coders, assigning a performance level score (0-4) to each of the eight items in the McNeill rubric. The McNeill instrument defines Level 0 as ?not descriptive of the lesson? and Level 4 as ?very descriptive of the lesson.? A scoring rubric was developed to identify the characteristics of each performance level, and the coders were trained prior to any data collection. Twenty-nine percent of the videos (n = 6) were scored by both coders. Interclass correlation coefficients (K) that ranked in the range of 0.75-1.00 were considered excellent and ranks between 0.60-0.74 were considered good (Cicchetti 1994). The interclass correlation coefficients for videos scored by both coders was K = 0.748, therefore, right at the borderline of a good-excellent rank in inter-rater reliability of data interpretation. For all co-scored videos, discrepancies in item scores between raters were deliberated on until mutual consensus was reached.  The coding team consisted of Dr. Tory Williams, and an undergraduate student finishing her senior year, Ms. Bianca Umali. 

 

The McNeill items were represented three subcategories: Investigating Practices (Items 1, 3, 5), Sense-Making Practices (Items 2, 4, 6), and Critiquing Practices (Items 7, 8; McNeill, et al. 2015). Summing scores from each of the items per subcategory, and then averaging across all teachers yielded summary performance within subcategories. Summing scores of all eight items, and then averaging across teachers determined summary total performance on the McNeill Rubric. 

 

Significant findings from the project include the use of the NGSS assessment instrument developed by McNeill.  In past projects that the PI has worked with (DESIE-0455811, DRL-1418183, DRL-0822286) classroom practice was primarily assessed using a modified version of the Reformed Teaching Observation Protocol (RTOP).  That instrument, while showing the ability to assess general student-centered pedagogical practices is not explicitly aligned to the practices associated with NGSS.  The McNeill instrument was shown to be easy to employ and could obtain high reliability. 

 

The second significant finding is associated several noted statistical significant differences among the various elements of the McNeill instrument.  While no statistical significant differentiation were found in our sample among the three main categories (Investigative, Sensemaking and Critiquing) we did find statistical significant differences among the 8 individual practices.   This finding could provide information for how to provide targeted teacher professional development efforts in the future.  Teacher professional development interventions are expensive and identifying specific practices that are the most challenging can therefore allow various educational agencies be more strategic. 

 

The detailed statistical analysis (including results from various statistical analyses as well as their graphical representation can be found in the attached image.
